'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 19, 'created_at': '2021-07-08T13:24:34Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-07T23:26:26Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': 'resolved', 'body': "Hello,

We are using multiple AKS clusters that we created using `terraform`. These clusters have been upgraded all the way until `1.18.17`, but it shouldn't matter much. I am _confident_ that only one of my AKS is not zone-aware, but I need more than confidence.

My problem is that I cannot figure out whether my cluster control plane is `zone aware` as defined in https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/aks/availability-zones#create-an-aks-cluster-across-availability-zones. Neither the Azure portal or the Az cli provides me with that information. I find that very disturbing that the information isn't captured in a payload that is rendered somewhere.

As stated, let me quote:
```If you don't define any zones for the default agent pool when you create an AKS cluster, control plane components are not guaranteed to spread across availability zones. You can add additional node pools using the az aks nodepool add command and specify --zones for new nodes, but it will not change how the control plane has been spread across zones. Availability zone settings can only be defined at cluster or node pool create-time.```
I have since then modified my node pools for various reason, deleted some, re-created others, I do now have a multi-zone nodePool, but according to what is said, I am not resilient to a zone failure. The concept of `defaultNodePool` seems a little odd now that the nodepools definitino has slighty changed and the taints like `System` or `User` seem to be the new Azure way of dealing with stuff.

My question, or my feature request is the following: How do I make _sure_ that a cluster control plan is distributed accross zones _or_ is not. I need a straightforward answer from a trustable source in order to adjust my company's disaster plan.

Thanks!
", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/2432/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/2432/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/comments/1061245709', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/Azure/AKS/issues/2432#issuecomment-1061245709', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/2432', 'id': 1061245709, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOBnR4Tc4_QVMN', 'user': {'login': 'seguler', 'id': 22362788, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjIyMzYyNzg4', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/22362788?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/seguler', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-07T23:26:26Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-07T23:26:26Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'body': 'Unfortunately, there is no way to check if an existing cluster is AZ enabled or not. It does make sense to provide this visibility to customers, however, we do have a roadmap item to convert all non-AZ enabled clusters to AZ enabled clusters for every region where multiple AZs are available. In my opinion, this will eliminate the need for your ask (a way to identify whether your cluster is AZ enabled or not), because it will be AZ enabled as long as it is in such a region. Does this make sense? 

I am trying to identify the timelines for this. When I know it concretely, I can share it here.', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/comments/1061245709/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'<!--

This issue tracker is a best-effort forum for users and customers to suggest features and report bugs.

If you are experiencing a service disruption when creating, upgrading, scaling, or deleting your cluster,
please open a support request with Azure support. Be sure to include your subscription id, resource group,
cluster name, and region. This information should __NOT__ be included in this issue due to its potential
sensitivity.

-->

<!--

Security issues should be reported to secure@microsoft.com and not via this public issue tracker.

-->

**What happened**:  AKS currently checks the node health within a 10 min timeframe before triggering Auto Repair. 

**What you expected to happen**:  Customer need to have the ability to change the timeframe. Like we should be able to reduce it to 1 min if required"

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:  There was a production outage when one of the server in VMSS was unhealthy due to an Network device failure at Azure and this caused a production outage as the node that failed was an active node receiving traffic plus it had pod having DNS running. 


**Anything else we need to know?**:

**Environment**: Production
- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`): 1.18.8
- Size of cluster (how many worker nodes are in the cluster?) AutoScales between 25 to 40 majority of the time. 
- General description of workloads in the cluster (e.g. HTTP microservices, Java app, Ruby on Rails, machine learning, etc.) Hosts Mobile App
- Others:
', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/2273/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/2273/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/comments/1024821863', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/Azure/AKS/issues/2273#issuecomment-1024821863', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/2273', 'id': 1024821863, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOBnR4Tc49FYpn', 'user': {'login': 'seguler', 'id': 22362788, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjIyMzYyNzg4', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/22362788?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/seguler', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-01-29T03:26:41Z', 'updated_at': '2022-01-29T03:26:41Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'body': "Hi @Gopinath-Radhakrishnan 

We have a plan to further optimize the 10-min threshold so we could help customers avoid outages like this. 

In the meantime, why was the application still receiving traffic? When the node is not reachable, the node will be taken out of the load balancer backend and the pod should not receive traffic. 

Also, was your pod not automatically scheduled to another node? When a node is in not ready state, after the pod eviction timeout, the pod will be evicted and recreated on a healthy node. Thanks to these two, you shouldn't really care about the 10-min threshold. Could you detail what the issue exactly was and what was observed?", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/comments/1024821863/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'state': 'open', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 15, 'created_at': '2021-07-08T13:24:34Z', 'updated_at': '2022-01-29T03:21:10Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "Hello,

We are using multiple AKS clusters that we created using `terraform`. These clusters have been upgraded all the way until `1.18.17`, but it shouldn't matter much. I am _confident_ that only one of my AKS is not zone-aware, but I need more than confidence.

My problem is that I cannot figure out whether my cluster control plane is `zone aware` as defined in https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/aks/availability-zones#create-an-aks-cluster-across-availability-zones. Neither the Azure portal or the Az cli provides me with that information. I find that very disturbing that the information isn't captured in a payload that is rendered somewhere.

As stated, let me quote:
```If you don't define any zones for the default agent pool when you create an AKS cluster, control plane components are not guaranteed to spread across availability zones. You can add additional node pools using the az aks nodepool add command and specify --zones for new nodes, but it will not change how the control plane has been spread across zones. Availability zone settings can only be defined at cluster or node pool create-time.```
I have since then modified my node pools for various reason, deleted some, re-created others, I do now have a multi-zone nodePool, but according to what is said, I am not resilient to a zone failure. The concept of `defaultNodePool` seems a little odd now that the nodepools definitino has slighty changed and the taints like `System` or `User` seem to be the new Azure way of dealing with stuff.

My question, or my feature request is the following: How do I make _sure_ that a cluster control plan is distributed accross zones _or_ is not. I need a straightforward answer from a trustable source in order to adjust my company's disaster plan.

Thanks!
", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/2432/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/2432/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/comments/1024820951', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/Azure/AKS/issues/2432#issuecomment-1024820951', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/Azure/AKS/issues/2432', 'id': 1024820951, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOBnR4Tc49FYbX', 'user': {'login': 'seguler', 'id': 22362788, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjIyMzYyNzg4', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/22362788?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/seguler', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/seguler/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-01-29T03:21:10Z', 'updated_at': '2022-01-29T03:21:10Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'body': "You do not change the availability zones of your control plane by changing the nodepools as it is written in the doc:

_You can add additional node pools using the az aks nodepool add command and specify --zones for new nodes, but it will not change how the control plane has been spread across zones._

If you want to make sure that your control plane is zone resilient, you need to create the cluster with the desired zone setting. Based on your description, your cluster's control plane is not zone resilient.
